title: High Frequency Gain-Dependent Word Recognition
chief_complaint: I am having significant trouble understanding speech, and I want to know if amplification will actually improve my clarity.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Reduced speech clarity, potential concern for cochlear dead regions.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty recognizing words, particularly high-frequency consonants.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To determine if high-frequency amplification improves speech understanding or if cochlear distortion limits benefit.

history.present_illness: Four adult patients presented with high-frequency (>1000 Hz) hearing thresholds greater than 55 dB HL and baseline Word Recognition Scores (WRS) of 80% or poorer.
history.otologic_history: Sensorineural hearing loss ranging from mild-to-moderate to severe/profound.
history.prior_management: Assessment of potential for high-frequency amplification benefit versus cochlear dead regions.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Four distinct audiometric configurations presented (Cases A-D). All show high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss greater than 55 dB HL above 1000 Hz. Case A and B: Mild to moderate SNHL. Case C: Mild to profound SNHL. Case D: Severe SNHL (PTA = 88 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Word recognition measured under two conditions: 1) Original baseline (phonemically balanced CVC words). 2) High-frequency gain-adjusted (14 dB additional gain >1000 Hz). Presentation levels adjusted for audibility (80-85 dB HL for A-C; 100 dB HL for D). All four cases showed significant improvement with HF gain, contrary to concerns about cochlear dead regions.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation of four adults with varying degrees of high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss demonstrated that adding 14 dB of gain above 1000 Hz significantly improved word recognition scores in all cases. Improvements ranged from 25% to 40% over baseline scores. This suggests that despite the severity of loss or potential for cochlear dead regions, these patients retained the capacity to utilize high-frequency speech cues when made audible.
counseling_points: Although you have significant hearing loss in the high pitches, our testing shows that your nerves are still able to process speech sounds in that range.
When we added extra volume specifically to the high frequencies, your ability to understand words improved dramatically (by 25-40%).
This indicates that hearing aids programmed with sufficient high-frequency gain will likely provide significant benefit for speech clarity.
We do not see evidence that 'dead regions' in the inner ear will prevent you from benefiting from amplification.
notes_for_actor: This case represents a composite of four patients. Portray a patient with significant difficulty understanding speech who might be skeptical that hearing aids will help because 'making it louder doesn't make it clearer' in their past experience.
Express surprise and satisfaction when the 'high frequency gain' condition is simulated, as the clarity of words improves noticeably.
